cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
In which year was the first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible, of the Davies's County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To determine the year of the first robbery for which Jesse James was known to be responsible, we need to look into historical records regarding Jesse James and his criminal activities. Jesse James was a notorious outlaw in the United States during the 19th century, and one of his early and significant robberies was the one at the Davies County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. 

Historical accounts indicate that this robbery occurred on February 13, 1866. During this robbery, Jesse James shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets, which marked a notable event in his criminal career.

Answer:
1866

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
In which year was the first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible, of the Davies's County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Jesse James did not become well-known until December 7, 1869, when he and (most likely) Frank robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. The robbery netted little money. Jesse is believed to have shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets, mistakenly believing him to be Samuel P. Cox, the militia officer who had killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War.\n', 'On December 7, 1869, Frank and Jesse James are believed to have robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. Jesse is suspected of having shot down the cashier, John W. Sheets, in the mistaken belief that he was Samuel P. Cox, the Union militia officer who had ambushed and killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War. The James brothers were unknown up to this point; this may have been their first robbery. Their names were later added to previous robberies as an afterthought.\n', "On December 7, 1869, two men (reported to be Frank and Jesse James) robbed the Daviess County Savings Association Bank and in the process shot the cashier John W. Sheets in the head and heart. Although there was $700 in the bank the robbers left with only $5 in fractional currency. The men were encountered near Kidder, Missouri where one of the men (believed to be Jesse) said that he was the brother of Bill Anderson and that he had avenged Anderson's murder by Cox.\n", 'In 1858, his family moved to Gallatin, Missouri where they rented property from the father of John W. Sheets (who became the first "official" victim of the James-Younger gang when they robbed the Daviess County Savings & Loan Association in 1869).\n', "Daviess County played a major role in the history of the outlaw James-Younger Gang. The first confirmed bank robbery involving Jesse James occurred on December 7, 1869 at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin. John W. Sheets, the bank cashier, was killed in the process by Jesse James, who believed Sheets was Samuel P. Cox, who had killed James's bushwhacker colleague Bloody Bill Anderson during the American Civil War. On July 15, 1881, the gang was believed to have been responsible for the robbery of the Rock Island Line at Winston in which a conductor and passenger were killed.\n", 'The Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, was robbed on February 13, 1866, making it one of the earliest documented daylight bank robberies. The robbers escaped with at least $60,000 () and killed a bystander outside. The robbery is believed to have been conducted by a group of former Confederate guerrillas, possibly led by Jesse James or Archie Clement, which became known as the James–Younger Gang.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1869 – American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery in Gallatin, Missouri.\n', "Beginning in 1866, Clements led his supporters into a new profession: bank robbery, especially of banks associated with Missouri Unionists. On February 13, a group of gunmen carried out the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robbery in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, stealing more than $58,000 in cash and bonds. The bank was owned and operated by former Union militia officers, who recently had conducted the first Republican Party rally in Clay County's history. The state authorities suspected Archie Clements of leading the raid and offered a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects would grow to include Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrette, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Gregg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister). During the escape through the streets of Liberty, one of the gang shot dead an innocent bystander named George Wymore. A string of robberies followed, many linked to Clements's gang. The hold-up most clearly linked to them was of Alexander Mitchell and Company in Lexington, Missouri, on October 30, 1866, in which they stole $2,000.\n", 'The Gallatin Bank Robbery marked the first time that Frank and Jesse were formally identified as bank robbers. A reward of $3,000 was raised for their capture. Jesse sent a letter to the Kansas City Times saying that he was innocent and could prove he was not in the area. He said he would surrender but was concerned that he would be lynched before he could prove his innocence.\n', "On February 13, 1866, a group of gunmen carried out one of the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robberies in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri. The outlaws stole some $60,000 in cash and bonds and killed a bystander on the street outside the bank. State authorities suspected Archie Clement of leading the raid, and promptly issued a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects grew to include Jesse and Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrett, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Greg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus, and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister).\n"]

To address the question regarding the first robbery for which Jesse James was known to be responsible, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. This will help clarify the context and significance of the event.

### Extracted Content:

1. **Date and Location**: 
   - The robbery occurred on **December 7, 1869**, at the **Daviess County Savings Association** in **Gallatin, Missouri**. This specific date and location are crucial for establishing the historical context of Jesse James's criminal activities.

2. **Victim**:
   - The robbery resulted in the death of the bank cashier, **Captain John Sheets**. Jesse James shot him, mistakenly believing he was **Samuel P. Cox**, a Union militia officer involved in the death of a Confederate guerrilla leader, **Bloody Bill Anderson**. This detail highlights the personal motivations behind the violence, linking it to the Civil War's legacy.

3. **Robbery Outcome**:
   - The robbery netted little money, with the robbers leaving with only **$5** in fractional currency despite the bank having **$700**. This indicates that the robbery was not financially successful, which contrasts with the typical portrayal of bank robberies as lucrative.

4. **Significance of the Event**:
   - This robbery is noted as the first confirmed bank robbery involving Jesse James, marking a turning point in his notoriety. Prior to this event, he and his brother Frank were relatively unknown. The robbery led to a **$3,000 reward** for their capture, indicating the seriousness with which law enforcement viewed their actions.

5. **Historical Context**:
   - The passages reference the broader context of post-Civil War America, where former Confederate guerrillas, like Jesse James, turned to bank robbery as a means of livelihood. The mention of **Bloody Bill Anderson** and **Samuel P. Cox** connects the robbery to the ongoing tensions and personal vendettas stemming from the Civil War.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

- **Historical Context**: Understanding the time period (post-Civil War) is essential for grasping the motivations behind Jesse James's actions. The Civil War had left deep scars in American society, and many former soldiers turned to crime as a means of survival or revenge.

- **Character Motivation**: The mistaken identity of Captain John Sheets as Samuel P. Cox adds a layer of complexity to Jesse James's character, portraying him not just as a criminal but as someone driven by a personal vendetta. This insight helps to humanize him and provides a narrative that explains his violent actions.

- **Impact on Reputation**: The robbery's outcome and the subsequent reward for the James brothers' capture played a significant role in establishing their reputation as notorious outlaws. This event marked the beginning of their infamy, which would grow in the years to come.

- **Financial Implications**: The fact that the robbery yielded very little money challenges the romanticized view of bank robbers as wealthy criminals. It suggests that many robberies were desperate acts rather than calculated financial ventures.

In summary, the extracted content provides essential background information that enhances understanding of Jesse James's first robbery, illustrating its significance in his life and the broader historical context of the time. This context is vital for comprehending the motivations behind his actions and the implications for his legacy as an outlaw.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on Jesse James and the Daviess County Savings Association Robbery**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The first robbery attributed to Jesse James occurred on December 7, 1869, at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. This event is significant not only because it marked the beginning of Jesse's notoriety but also because it was a violent act that resulted in the death of the cashier, Captain John Sheets. The robbery itself yielded very little money—only $5—indicating perhaps a desperate or poorly planned operation. This robbery is often seen as the moment when the James brothers transitioned from obscurity to infamy.

**Expert 2: Criminal Psychology Analyst**
From a psychological perspective, Jesse's actions during the robbery reflect a complex interplay of personal vendetta and misidentification. He shot Captain Sheets, believing him to be Samuel P. Cox, the Union officer responsible for the death of his comrade, Bloody Bill Anderson. This suggests that Jesse's motivations were not purely financial but were also deeply rooted in the trauma of the Civil War and a desire for revenge. This adds a layer of understanding to his character, portraying him as a product of his violent environment.

**Expert 3: Law Enforcement Historian**
It's important to note that the Daviess County robbery was pivotal in the evolution of law enforcement's response to organized crime in the post-Civil War era. The robbery led to a significant reward being offered for Jesse and Frank James, marking the beginning of a more concerted effort to capture them. This incident also set a precedent for how law enforcement would deal with outlaw gangs in the future, as it highlighted the need for more organized and strategic approaches to combating such criminal activities.

**Expert 4: Cultural Impact Scholar**
The Daviess County robbery also had lasting cultural implications. It was the first time Jesse and Frank James were publicly identified as bank robbers, which contributed to their legendary status in American folklore. The narrative surrounding this robbery has been romanticized in various forms of media, portraying the James brothers as anti-heroes. This cultural lens influences how we perceive their actions and the broader context of lawlessness in the American West.

**Points of Agreement:**
All experts agree on the date of the robbery (December 7, 1869) and its significance as Jesse James's first confirmed bank robbery. They also concur that the event had profound implications for both Jesse's personal narrative and the broader societal context of law enforcement and cultural mythology.

**Points of Disagreement:**
While there is consensus on the facts, there are differing interpretations of Jesse's motivations. The Historical Context Specialist emphasizes the financial aspect, while the Criminal Psychology Analyst focuses on the psychological motivations tied to revenge and trauma. Additionally, the Cultural Impact Scholar highlights the narrative construction around the event, suggesting that the public perception of Jesse James has overshadowed the actual historical events.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The discussion reveals that the Daviess County Savings Association robbery is a multifaceted event that serves as a critical juncture in American history. It marks the transformation of Jesse James from a relatively unknown figure into a notorious outlaw, driven by complex motivations that intertwine personal vendetta with the socio-political landscape of post-Civil War America. The robbery not only initiated a new chapter in Jesse's life but also influenced law enforcement practices and shaped the cultural narrative surrounding outlaws in the American West.

In conclusion, the perspectives of the experts enrich our understanding of the robbery by highlighting its historical significance, psychological implications, law enforcement responses, and cultural ramifications, illustrating how a single event can resonate across multiple domains of knowledge.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
In which year was the first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible, of the Davies's County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Jesse James did not become well-known until December 7, 1869, when he and (most likely) Frank robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. The robbery netted little money. Jesse is believed to have shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets, mistakenly believing him to be Samuel P. Cox, the militia officer who had killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War.
', 'On December 7, 1869, Frank and Jesse James are believed to have robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. Jesse is suspected of having shot down the cashier, John W. Sheets, in the mistaken belief that he was Samuel P. Cox, the Union militia officer who had ambushed and killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War. The James brothers were unknown up to this point; this may have been their first robbery. Their names were later added to previous robberies as an afterthought.
', "On December 7, 1869, two men (reported to be Frank and Jesse James) robbed the Daviess County Savings Association Bank and in the process shot the cashier John W. Sheets in the head and heart. Although there was $700 in the bank the robbers left with only $5 in fractional currency. The men were encountered near Kidder, Missouri where one of the men (believed to be Jesse) said that he was the brother of Bill Anderson and that he had avenged Anderson's murder by Cox.
", 'In 1858, his family moved to Gallatin, Missouri where they rented property from the father of John W. Sheets (who became the first "official" victim of the James-Younger gang when they robbed the Daviess County Savings & Loan Association in 1869).
', "Daviess County played a major role in the history of the outlaw James-Younger Gang. The first confirmed bank robbery involving Jesse James occurred on December 7, 1869 at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin. John W. Sheets, the bank cashier, was killed in the process by Jesse James, who believed Sheets was Samuel P. Cox, who had killed James's bushwhacker colleague Bloody Bill Anderson during the American Civil War. On July 15, 1881, the gang was believed to have been responsible for the robbery of the Rock Island Line at Winston in which a conductor and passenger were killed.
", 'The Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, was robbed on February 13, 1866, making it one of the earliest documented daylight bank robberies. The robbers escaped with at least $60,000 () and killed a bystander outside. The robbery is believed to have been conducted by a group of former Confederate guerrillas, possibly led by Jesse James or Archie Clement, which became known as the James–Younger Gang.
', 'BULLET::::- 1869 – American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery in Gallatin, Missouri.
', "Beginning in 1866, Clements led his supporters into a new profession: bank robbery, especially of banks associated with Missouri Unionists. On February 13, a group of gunmen carried out the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robbery in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, stealing more than $58,000 in cash and bonds. The bank was owned and operated by former Union militia officers, who recently had conducted the first Republican Party rally in Clay County's history. The state authorities suspected Archie Clements of leading the raid and offered a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects would grow to include Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrette, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Gregg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister). During the escape through the streets of Liberty, one of the gang shot dead an innocent bystander named George Wymore. A string of robberies followed, many linked to Clements's gang. The hold-up most clearly linked to them was of Alexander Mitchell and Company in Lexington, Missouri, on October 30, 1866, in which they stole $2,000.
", 'The Gallatin Bank Robbery marked the first time that Frank and Jesse were formally identified as bank robbers. A reward of $3,000 was raised for their capture. Jesse sent a letter to the Kansas City Times saying that he was innocent and could prove he was not in the area. He said he would surrender but was concerned that he would be lynched before he could prove his innocence.
', "On February 13, 1866, a group of gunmen carried out one of the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robberies in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri. The outlaws stole some $60,000 in cash and bonds and killed a bystander on the street outside the bank. State authorities suspected Archie Clement of leading the raid, and promptly issued a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects grew to include Jesse and Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrett, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Greg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus, and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister).
"]

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the first robbery attributed to Jesse James. Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Date and Location**: The first confirmed robbery involving Jesse James occurred on **December 7, 1869**, at the **Daviess County Savings Association** in **Gallatin, Missouri**.
2. **Participants**: Jesse James, along with his brother Frank, is believed to have committed the robbery.
3. **Incident Details**: During the robbery, Jesse shot and killed the cashier, **Captain John Sheets**, mistakenly believing him to be **Samuel P. Cox**, a Union militia officer associated with the death of a colleague, **Bloody Bill Anderson**, during the Civil War.
4. **Outcome of the Robbery**: The robbery netted very little money, with the robbers leaving with only **$5** despite there being **$700** in the bank.
5. **Significance**: This robbery marked the first time Frank and Jesse James were formally identified as bank robbers, leading to a reward of **$3,000** for their capture.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Temporal Relationships**: The clear date of the robbery allows the model to understand the sequence of events in historical context. Recognizing that this was Jesse James's first confirmed robbery helps establish a timeline for his criminal activities and their escalation.

2. **Causal Connections**: The mistaken identity that led to the shooting of Captain John Sheets illustrates a causal relationship between the robbery's chaotic nature and the tragic outcome. This can enhance the model's ability to infer how misunderstandings and misidentifications can lead to unintended consequences, a critical aspect of causal reasoning.

3. **Motivations and Consequences**: Understanding Jesse's motivations—avenging a colleague's death—provides insight into the psychological and social factors that drive criminal behavior. This can improve the model's ability to infer motivations behind actions and their subsequent effects on individuals and society.

4. **Statistical Inference**: The contrast between the amount of money available and what was actually taken can inform the model about risk assessment and decision-making in high-stakes situations. This can enhance the model's ability to evaluate outcomes based on available resources versus potential gains.

5. **Identification and Reputation**: The formal identification of the James brothers as bank robbers following this incident can help the model understand how actions can shape public perception and reputation, which is crucial for analyzing social dynamics and historical narratives.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating this information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by learning to recognize patterns, understand motivations, and evaluate the consequences of actions within a historical context. This enhances the model's ability to engage in more nuanced reasoning about human behavior and historical events.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
In which year was the first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible, of the Davies's County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets?
answer:
Reasoning process:
To determine the year of the first robbery for which Jesse James was known to be responsible, we need to look into historical records regarding Jesse James and his criminal activities. Jesse James was a notorious outlaw in the United States during the 19th century, and one of his early and significant robberies was the one at the Davies County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. 

Historical accounts indicate that this robbery occurred on February 13, 1866. During this robbery, Jesse James shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets, which marked a notable event in his criminal career.

Answer:
1866

It is essential to note that this robbery occurred on **December 7, 1869**, not February 13, 1866, as previously stated. This date is confirmed by multiple historical accounts.

During this incident, Jesse shot and killed the cashier, **Captain John Sheets**, mistakenly believing him to be **Samuel P. Cox**, a Union officer involved in the death of his associate, **Bloody Bill Anderson**. This mistaken identity highlights the chaotic nature of the robbery and the emotional motivations behind Jesse's actions.

3. **Outcome and Significance**: The robbery netted very little money, with the robbers leaving with only **$5** despite there being **$700** in the bank. This outcome illustrates the risks and unpredictability associated with criminal activities. Furthermore, this robbery marked the first time Frank and Jesse James were formally identified as bank robbers, leading to a significant reward of **$3,000** for their capture. This identification had lasting implications for their reputations and future criminal endeavors.

The first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible occurred in **1869** at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To determine the year of the first robbery for which Jesse James was known to be responsible, we need to examine historical records regarding his criminal activities. Jesse James was a notorious outlaw in the United States during the 19th century, and one of his early significant robberies was at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri.

Upon reviewing authoritative sources, it is established that the first confirmed bank robbery involving Jesse James occurred on **December 7, 1869**, not February 13, 1866, as previously stated. During this robbery, Jesse James shot and killed the cashier, **John W. Sheets**, mistakenly believing him to be **Samuel P. Cox**, a Union militia officer involved in the death of "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War. 

This robbery is notable for several reasons:
1. **Date and Location**: The robbery took place on **December 7, 1869**, at the **Daviess County Savings Association** in **Gallatin, Missouri**.
2. **Circumstances**: Jesse James's actions during the robbery were driven by a personal vendetta, as he believed Sheets was Cox.
3. **Financial Outcome**: Despite the bank having **$700**, the robbers left with only **$5** in fractional currency, highlighting the ineffectiveness of the robbery.
4. **Identification**: This event marked the first time that Frank and Jesse James were formally identified as bank robbers, which is crucial for understanding their criminal history.
5. **Public Reaction**: A reward of **$3,000** was raised for their capture, indicating the seriousness with which law enforcement and the public viewed their actions.

This updated information clarifies the historical context of Jesse James's criminal activities and corrects the timeline of his first robbery.

**Answer:**
1869

question_info.question: In which year was the first robbery for which it is known that Jesse James was responsible, of the Davies's County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri, during which Jesse shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets?
passages:
Jesse James did not become well-known until December 7, 1869, when he and (most likely) Frank robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. The robbery netted little money. Jesse is believed to have shot and killed the cashier, Captain John Sheets, mistakenly believing him to be Samuel P. Cox, the militia officer who had killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War.
On December 7, 1869, Frank and Jesse James are believed to have robbed the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin, Missouri. Jesse is suspected of having shot down the cashier, John W. Sheets, in the mistaken belief that he was Samuel P. Cox, the Union militia officer who had ambushed and killed "Bloody Bill" Anderson during the Civil War. The James brothers were unknown up to this point; this may have been their first robbery. Their names were later added to previous robberies as an afterthought.
On December 7, 1869, two men (reported to be Frank and Jesse James) robbed the Daviess County Savings Association Bank and in the process shot the cashier John W. Sheets in the head and heart. Although there was $700 in the bank the robbers left with only $5 in fractional currency. The men were encountered near Kidder, Missouri where one of the men (believed to be Jesse) said that he was the brother of Bill Anderson and that he had avenged Anderson's murder by Cox.
In 1858, his family moved to Gallatin, Missouri where they rented property from the father of John W. Sheets (who became the first "official" victim of the James-Younger gang when they robbed the Daviess County Savings & Loan Association in 1869).
Daviess County played a major role in the history of the outlaw James-Younger Gang. The first confirmed bank robbery involving Jesse James occurred on December 7, 1869 at the Daviess County Savings Association in Gallatin. John W. Sheets, the bank cashier, was killed in the process by Jesse James, who believed Sheets was Samuel P. Cox, who had killed James's bushwhacker colleague Bloody Bill Anderson during the American Civil War. On July 15, 1881, the gang was believed to have been responsible for the robbery of the Rock Island Line at Winston in which a conductor and passenger were killed.
The Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, was robbed on February 13, 1866, making it one of the earliest documented daylight bank robberies. The robbers escaped with at least $60,000 () and killed a bystander outside. The robbery is believed to have been conducted by a group of former Confederate guerrillas, possibly led by Jesse James or Archie Clement, which became known as the James–Younger Gang.
BULLET::::- 1869 – American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery in Gallatin, Missouri.
Beginning in 1866, Clements led his supporters into a new profession: bank robbery, especially of banks associated with Missouri Unionists. On February 13, a group of gunmen carried out the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robbery in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri, stealing more than $58,000 in cash and bonds. The bank was owned and operated by former Union militia officers, who recently had conducted the first Republican Party rally in Clay County's history. The state authorities suspected Archie Clements of leading the raid and offered a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects would grow to include Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrette, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Gregg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister). During the escape through the streets of Liberty, one of the gang shot dead an innocent bystander named George Wymore. A string of robberies followed, many linked to Clements's gang. The hold-up most clearly linked to them was of Alexander Mitchell and Company in Lexington, Missouri, on October 30, 1866, in which they stole $2,000.
The Gallatin Bank Robbery marked the first time that Frank and Jesse were formally identified as bank robbers. A reward of $3,000 was raised for their capture. Jesse sent a letter to the Kansas City Times saying that he was innocent and could prove he was not in the area. He said he would surrender but was concerned that he would be lynched before he could prove his innocence.
On February 13, 1866, a group of gunmen carried out one of the first daylight, peacetime, armed bank robberies in U.S. history when they held up the Clay County Savings Association in Liberty, Missouri. The outlaws stole some $60,000 in cash and bonds and killed a bystander on the street outside the bank. State authorities suspected Archie Clement of leading the raid, and promptly issued a reward for his capture. In later years, the list of suspects grew to include Jesse and Frank James, Cole Younger, John Jarrett, Oliver Shepard, Bud and Donny Pence, Frank Greg, Bill and James Wilkerson, Joab Perry, Ben Cooper, Red Mankus, and Allen Parmer (who later married Susan James, Frank and Jesse's sister).
